IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 9244 S1381-1169(14)00386-0 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.08.029 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 (a) Schematic diagram of the in situ DRIFTS experimental setup, (b) reaction cell and gas circuit. Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts with different molar ratio of Co/Mo. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the catalysts reduced at 773K with different molar ratio of Co/Mo. Fig. 4 XRD patterns of the catalysts with Co/Mo=0.5 reduced at the different temperatures. Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo. Fig. 6 XPS spectra of Mo 3d of the fresh catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo. Fig. 7 XPS spectra of Mo 3d of the catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo after reduction at 773K. Fig. 8 XPS spectra of Mo 3d of the catalysts with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 reduced at different temperatures. Fig. 9 DRIFTS spectra of syngas adsorption on the reduced catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo. Tel.: +86 551 6360 7492; fax: +86 551 6514 1078. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 551 6360 7492; fax: +86 551 6514 1078. Graphical abstract The addition of moderate amount of cobalt promoted the reduction of Mo species to Mo δ+ species. The adsorption strength of CO on the Mo δ+ site reached a maximum on the catalyst with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 and reduction temperature at 773K. The results were consistent with the catalytic activity of the catalysts. The K–Co–Mo/C catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo and reduction temperatures were prepared by a sol–gel method and characterized by the means of XRD, H2-TPR, XPS and in situ DRIFTS. The addition of moderate amount of cobalt can promote the reduction of Mo species to Mo δ+ species. With increasing the Co content, the CO adsorption strength on Mo δ+ species increased and was up to the maximum when Co/Mo=0.5. Further increasing the Co content led to the decrease of surface Mo δ+ species because that the formation of CoMoO3 inhibited the further reduction of Mo4+ species. Increasing the reduction temperature resulted in the decrease of the surface cobalt content significantly. The CO adsorption strength on Mo δ+ species reached a maximum at 773K. Higher reduction temperature caused the decrease of CO adsorption strength because of the sintering of catalyst. It suggested that the surface Mo δ+ species is responsible for the alcohol synthesis. The high activity of the K–Co–Mo/C catalysts with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 for alcohol synthesis should be attributed to its high Mo δ+ content on the surface. Keyword K–Co–Mo/C Mixed alcohol synthesis In situ DRIFTS Syngas adsorption 1 Introduction The high depletion of nonrenewable energy resources and the crude price of oil have accelerated the development on the alternative energy. The synthesis of mixed alcohols from syngas (CO and H2) is a potential approach to the production of clean fuels, petrochemical substitution and chemical feedstock [1–3]. Several catalytic systems were developed for the reaction in the past decades [4–7]. Among these, molybdenum-based catalysts are more attractive for potential commercial aspects because of their high catalytic activity and excellent resistance to sulfur [8,9]. It was found that the cobalt is an effective promoter of the Mo-based catalyst for enhancing the alcohol production, especially improving the C2+ alcohol selectivity. Xiang et al. [10] studied the K/Co/β-Mo2C catalysts and found that the cobalt can exert strong promotion for carbon chain grown, especially for the stage of methanol to ethanol. Li et al. [11] also reported the promotional effect of cobalt of Co–Mo–K/C catalyst for high alcohol synthesis. The cobalt species operated as a synergistic system with MoS2 phase, rather than independently from the MoS2 phase. Surisetty et al. [12] proved that the addition of cobalt to K-MoS2/MWCNTS catalyst not only increased the number of surface molybdenum sites, but also promoted the reducibility of molybdenum, which enhanced the total alcohol space time yield (STY) and the selectivity of ethanol. In terms of syngas adsorption, some researchers reported that the linear-type CO adsorption is the main active site for the formation of hydrocarbons, while the bridge-type CO adsorption is the main active site for the formation of oxygenated compounds [1,13]. Kumar et al. [14] studied the effect of cobalt precursors of CoRe catalyst on CO adsorption behavior. For CoRe (N) catalyst synthesized with cobalt nitrate, the CO hydrogenation took place on bridge-type adsorbed Co sites. For the CoRe (A) catalyst synthesized with cobalt acetate, the weak linearly adsorbed CO on the active sites facilitated the M–CO bond dissociation and increased the CO insertion, leading to the higher oxygenate selectivity. Cao et al. [15] observed that there were only linear CO bands on the Co sites for the Cu-Co bimetallic catalysts and the multiple CO molecules adsorbed on the Co sites could explain the selectivity for enhanced oxygenate formation via CO insertion reaction. In general, the effect of cobalt promoter on the catalyst structure and syngas adsorption for high alcohol synthesis is still under debate. In previous work, our group developed a highly homogeneous and dispersed K–Co–Mo/C catalyst by a modified sol–gel method, which exhibits high alcohol yield, especially high C2+OH selectivity for mixed alcohol synthesis [16–18]. The optimized Co/Mo ratio and reduction temperature were 0.5 and 773K, respectively. In this work, a series of K–Co–Mo/C catalysts with different cobalt contents and reduction temperatures were prepared. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used to investigate the structure, reducibility and surface chemical composition of the catalysts, respectively. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), as a useful surface-sensitive technique, was employed to analyze the adsorbed species on the surface of catalysts under reaction condition. Based on the results, the effect of the cobalt content and reduction temperature on the surface chemical composition and adsorbed species of the K–Co–Mo/C catalyst was studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The K–Co–Mo/C catalyst was synthesized by a sol–gel method. A typical procedure is as follows: the Co(NO3)2 (AR) aqueous solution was added slowly to the (NH4)6Mo7O2 6H2O (AR) aqueous solution and formed a purple precipitate with adding drops of NH3 H2O. Then, the citric acid (AR), as complexant, was added into the solution under constant stirring until the precipitates were dissolved. The molar ratio of citric acid to metallic ions was 0.4. Subsequently, the K2CO3 (AR) aqueous solution was dropped slowly to the solution with a K/Mo molar ratio of 0.1. After adjusting the pH value of the solution to 3.5, the mixed solution was kept in a water bath at 343K for 6h to form the gel. The as-prepared gel was dried at 393K for 15h and then calcined in the nitrogen flow at 673K for 4h. The samples were reduced in 5% H2/N2 with a flow rate of 60ml/min for 12h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The phase composition and crystalline structure of catalysts were measured using Rigaku TTR-III X-ray powder diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source at 40kV in the range of 10–70°. The reducibility of the catalysts was studied by the H2-TPR. For each experiment, about 50mg of catalyst was used. The catalyst was first purged in a fixed-bed system in argon at 423K for 1h to remove the trace of water and then cooled to room temperature. TPR was performed in 5% H2/Ar with a flow rate of 60ml/min from room temperature to 1073K with a heating rate of 10K/min. The surface chemical composition of the catalyst was analyzed by the XPS spectra recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer using Al Kα (hv =1486.6eV) X-ray source. 2.3 In situ DRIFTS In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed on a Bruker IFS 66 v/s FTIR spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector, KBr beamsplitter and an in situ reaction cell in conjunction with a praying mantis DRIFTS accessory (Harrick Scientific). The schematic diagram of the experimental setup was shown in Fig. 1a. The reaction cell is equipped with a heating system and a sample cup covered by a dome fitted with ZnSe windows. The cooling water was circulated through a coil surrounding the base of the dome to facilitate temperature regulation and rapid cooling of the cell after the set-temperature was adjusted (Fig. 1b). For each experiment, approximately 20mg fresh catalyst was placed in the sample cup. Syngas adsorption was carried out at room temperature by introducing the syngas (H2/CO=2) to the reaction cell at a rate of 5ml/min for 30min. All the infrared spectra in the region of 4000–600cm−1 were recorded in reflectance mode with 256 scans and a resolution of 4cm−1 at a scan velocity of 20KHz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD The XRD pattern of the fresh catalysts with different molar ratio of Co/Mo was shown in Fig. 2 . The catalyst without Co displayed the characteristic diffraction peaks of MoO2 (2θ =26.1°, 36.8°, 53.7°, 60.5°). The formation of Mo4+ species can be due to the fact that the decomposition of citric acid in nitrogen partly reduced the sample. For the sample of Co/Mo=0.3, almost no diffraction peaks were observed, indicating that the addition of Co can improve the dispersion of the Mo species and decrease the particle size. With the further increase of Co/Mo ratio, the diffraction peaks of MoO2 were observed again and the intensity of the peaks enhanced. When the molar ratio of Co/Mo was up to 0.7, besides the peaks of MoO2, the peaks of CoMoO3 (2θ =18.2°, 25.2°, 35.4°, 44.2°, 56.2°, 63.9°) were also detected. After reduction at 773K, the diffraction peaks of the catalysts almost have no change compared with the fresh catalysts except that the intensity slightly increases, as shown in Fig. 3 . The XRD patterns of the catalysts with Co/Mo=0.5 reduced at the different temperatures were given in Fig. 4 . When increasing the temperature from 673K to 773K, the peaks intensity of MoO2 phase was increased significantly, confirming the formation of more MoO2. When the reduction temperature was increasing to 873K, the diffraction peaks of Mo3Co3C (2θ =22.7°, 32.4°, 39.8°, 42.5°, 46.4°, 49.3°) were detected, indicating that too high reduction temperature may cause the sintering of the catalyst. 3.2 H2-TPR The H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts with the different molar ratios of Co/Mo were presented in Fig. 5 . Two broad peaks were observed at 730K and 918K for the catalyst without Co, which corresponded to the reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+ and the reduction of Mo4+ to Mo δ+, respectively [19]. For the catalyst with Co/Mo=0.3, one more peak was observed at 800K, corresponding to the reduction of Co2+ to Co+ [20]. For the catalyst with Co/Mo=0.5, the area of the peak at 918K was obviously larger than that of others, indicating that the addition of proper amount of Co promoted the reduction of Mo4+ and more Mo4+ was reduced to Mo δ+. As the Co/Mo ratio increased to 0.7, the reduction peak of Mo6+ and Co2+ shifted to lower temperatures of about 643K and 700K, respectively. The reduction temperature of MoO2 was slight higher and the area obviously decreased. A new peak at 1018K was observed, which can be attributed the reduction of Mo4+ in CoMoO3. The results indicate that the CoMoO3 is more difficult to be reduced than MoO2. 3.3 XPS XPS spectra of Mo 3d of the fresh catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo are shown in Fig. 6 . For the fresh catalyst, the two peaks at 235.5eV and 232.3eV were attributed to the binding energies of Mo6+ (3d3/2) and Mo6+ (3d5/2), respectively. The peaks at 233.6eV and 230.5eV were the binding energies of Mo4+ (3d3/2) and Mo4+ (3d5/2), respectively. The distribution of Mo species and surface composition of the catalysts are listed in Table 1 . It can be seen that the addition of cobalt resulted in the decrease of the Mo4+ species content. The reason may be attributed that the addition of Co(NO3)2 provided more oxygen species, which weakened the reducibility of the citric acid decomposition in nitrogen for the Mo species. At Co/Mo ratio of 0.7, the content of Mo4+ species became much higher, which should be due to the formation of new phase CoMoO3. After reduction, two new peaks at 231.8eV and 228.5eV appeared, as shown in Fig. 7 , which may be assigned to the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Mo δ+ (1< δ <4) [21]. The surface chemical composition of the reduced catalysts is listed in Table 2 . With increasing the Co content, the Mo4+ fraction decreased, while the percentage of Mo δ+ increased. The reason is that the addition of cobalt promoted the reduction of Mo4+ to Mo δ+ species, as revealed by H2-TRP result. Furthermore, at Co/Mo ratio of 0.7, the Mo4+ fraction became much higher and Mo δ+ content decreased remarkably, which is attributed that the formed CoMoO3 is more difficult to be reduced than MoO2. The XPS spectra of Mo 3d of the catalysts with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 reduced at different temperatures were collected and shown in Fig. 8 . It can be seen that in Table 2, with increasing the reduction temperature from 673K to 773K, the Mo6+ and Mo4+ content decreased, while the Mo δ+ fraction increased, indicating a higher reduction degree. However, further improving the temperature to 873K, the Mo6+ and Mo4+ content increased rather than decreased. The reason may be attributed that too high temperature caused the sintering of sample and made the reduction more difficult. For the cobalt species, it was observed that with increasing the reduction temperature, the surface cobalt content decreased significantly. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS Fig. 9 shows the DRIFTS spectra of syngas adsorption on the catalysts reduced at 773K. For the catalyst without Co, the broad bands at 2200–2150cm−1 and 2130–2100cm−1 can be assigned to the gaseous CO [22]. The bands at 2103cm−1 and 2064cm−1 were attributed to the linear stretching of CO adsorbed on Mo δ+ and Mo2+, respectively [12,23]. The weak bands at 2080–2100cm−1 can be assigned to the CO adsorption on the Mo center in lower oxidation state [23]. Besides, the bands at 2150cm−1 and 2138cm−1 may be assigned to CO adsorption on Mo-OH [24]. With cobalt addition, it was observed that the new bands at 2130cm−1, 2170cm−1 and 2186cm−1 appeared, which can be attributed to CO adsorbed on Co1+, Co2+ and Co x+ respectively [25]. Furthermore, the band intensity of CO adsorption on the Mo δ+ became stronger with cobalt addition and reached a maximum at Co/Mo ratio of 0.5. At higher Co/Mo ratio of 0.7, the band intensity of CO adsorption decreased, which can be due to the decrease of Mo δ+ species, as revealed by TPR and XPS results. Fig. 10 showed the DRIFTS spectra of syngas adsorption on the catalysts with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 reduced at different temperatures. The band intensity of CO adsorption on Mo δ+ became stronger when the reduction temperature was from 673K to 773K. Further increasing to 873K, the CO adsorption intensity decreased obviously. The result indicated that too high reduction temperature was unfavorable for syngas adsorption on catalyst because of the sintering of catalyst. These results indicated that the addition of cobalt promoted the syngas adsorption on Mo species. The possible reason is that electronic shift may occur between Co and Mo [22], resulting in a change of the adsorption property of the catalyst. Muramatsu et al. [26] reported that the MoO2−x species may be responsible for the formation of alcohols. Our previous study investigated the effects of Co content and reduction temperature on the catalytic performance for the alcohol synthesis of the K–Co–Mo/C catalysts [27,28]. The result indicated that the K–Co–Mo/C catalyst with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 and reduced at 773K shows the best catalytic activity for mixed alcohol synthesis. Combined with the characterization results in this study, it was believed that the high activity of K–Co–Mo/C with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 should be ascribed to its high Mo δ+ content on the surface. Further studies including the local structure of active component, reaction intermediates and reaction mechanism are in progress. 4 Conclusions For the K–Co–Mo/C catalyst prepared by sol–gel method, the addition of moderate amount of cobalt promoted the reduction of Mo species to Mo δ+. Higher Co content led to the formation of CoMoO3 which was more difficult to be reduced. Also, higher reduction temperature caused the formation of Co3Mo3C because of the sintering of the catalyst. The CO adsorption strength on Mo δ+ species reached a maximum on the catalyst with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 and reduction temperature of 773K. The surface Mo δ+ species is suggested to be responsible for the mixed alcohols synthesis from syngas. coredata.dc:description: The K–Co–Mo/C catalysts with different molar ratios of Co/Mo and reduction temperatures were prepared by a sol–gel method and characterized by the means of XRD, H2-TPR, XPS and in situ DRIFTS. The addition of moderate amount of cobalt can promote the reduction of Mo species to Mo δ+ species. With increasing the Co content, the CO adsorption strength on Mo δ+ species increased and was up to the maximum when Co/Mo=0.5. Further increasing the Co content led to the decrease of surface Mo δ+ species because that the formation of CoMoO3 inhibited the further reduction of Mo4+ species. Increasing the reduction temperature resulted in the decrease of the surface cobalt content significantly. The CO adsorption strength on Mo δ+ species reached a maximum at 773K. Higher reduction temperature caused the decrease of CO adsorption strength because of the sintering of catalyst. It suggested that the surface Mo δ+ species is responsible for the alcohol synthesis. The high activity of the K–Co–Mo/C catalysts with Co/Mo ratio of 0.5 for alcohol synthesis should be attributed to its high Mo δ+ content on the surface.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of cobalt promoter and reduction temperature on the surface species and syngas adsorption of K–Co–Mo/C catalyst for mixed alcohols synthesis
